raw_text:
Safety alert as GM recalls cars
 
 The world's biggest carmaker General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US on safety grounds, according to federal regulators.
 
 The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said the largest recall involves 155,465 pickups, vans and sports utility vehicles (SUVs). This is because of possible malfunctions with the braking systems. The affected vehicles in the product recall are from the 2004 and 2005 model years, GM said. Those vehicles with potential faults are the Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverade and Suburban; the GMC Savana, Sierra and Yukon.
 
 The NHTSA said a pressure accumulator in the braking system could crack during normal driving and fragments could injure people if the hood was open. This could allow hydraulic fluid to leak, which could make it harder to brake or steer and could cause a crash, it warned. GM is also recalling 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year. This is because the accelerator pedal may not work properly in extremely cold temperatures, requiring more braking. In addition, the car giant is calling back 17,815 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys and Isuzu Ascenders from the 2005 model years because the windshield is not properly fitted and could fall out in a crash. However, GM stressed that it did not know of any injuries related to the problems. News of the recall follows an announcement last month that GM expects earnings this year be lower than in 2004. The world's biggest car maker is grappling with losses in its European business, weak US sales and now a product recall. In January, GM said higher healthcare costs in North America, and lower profits at its financial services subsidiary would hurt its performance in 2005.
llama3.2:1b: General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US due to possible malfunctions with braking systems on certain models from 2004 and 2005.
The affected vehicles include Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverade, Suburban; GMC Savana, Sierra, Yukon.

Additionally, GM is recalling Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs, Pontiac Grand Prix sedans, Buick Raniers, Trailblazers, Envoys and Isuzu Ascenders from 2004 model year due to accelerator pedal issues in cold temperatures.
llama3.2:3b: General Motors is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US due to safety concerns.

The recalls involve:

- 155,465 vehicles with possible malfunctions in their braking systems (2004 and 2005 model years)
- 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans with faulty accelerators
- 17,815 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys and Isuzu Ascenders with improperly fitted windshields
gemma2:2b: General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US due to potential braking system malfunctions, windshield issues, and accelerator problems.
The recalls affect a variety of models from the 2004 and 2005 model years, with some potentially causing injuries if certain conditions arise.
These safety concerns come after GM's announcement of lower projected earnings for 2005 due to various factors including losses in Europe, weaker US sales, and higher healthcare costs.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A major automotive company has recalled nearly 200,000 vehicles due to potential brake system faults in the US.
The NHTSA states that most affected are pickups and SUVs from models between 2004 and 2005.
Some of these vehicles include Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Silverade, Yukon, GMC Savana, Sierra, Yukon, and Suburban.
The car giant is also recalling some Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs, and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year because of faulty accelerator pedals or windshield issues.
GM insists there are no injuries associated with these recalls but still claims it doesn't know of any accidents related to these problems.

News about the recall has followed a previous announcement indicating lower profits for the automotive company in North America and less financial performance in 2005 than during the previous fiscal year.
qwen2.5:1.5b: General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles due to potential braking system malfunctions and issues with accelerator pedals and windshield fits.
This recall affects pickups, vans, SUVs from the 2004 and 2005 model years, as well as certain luxury models from Cadillac, GMC, Pontiac, Buick, and Chevrolet.

The affected vehicles include problems with brake pressure accumulators cracking during normal driving, leading to hydraulic fluid leaks that could make it harder to brake or steer and potentially cause accidents in extreme cold temperatures.
No injuries have been reported related to the recalls.
qwen2.5:3b: Safety alert as GM recalls cars: The world's largest carmaker, General Motors (GM), is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles due to potential braking system malfunctions from the 2004 and 2005 model years.
Affected models include pickups, vans, SUVs like Chevrolet Avalanche, GMC Savana, and Cadillac XLR coupes among others.
The recall aims to address issues with a pressure accumulator in the braking systems that could crack under normal driving conditions, leading to fluid leaks and reduced braking performance.
Additionally, GM is recalling vehicles from Buick Ranier, Chevrolet Trailblazer, GMC Envoy, and Isuzu Ascender models due to windshield fitting problems.

While no injuries have been reported related to these issues, GM faces challenges including lower earnings in its European business, weak US sales, and increased healthcare costs impacting its financial performance.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) said the largest recall involves 155,465 pickups, vans and sports utility vehicles (SUVs).

smollm:1.7b: The safety alert as GM recalls nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US on safety grounds is a major concern for consumers.
The recall involves 155,465 pickups, vans and sports utility vehicles (SUVs) that are potentially faulty with their braking systems.
This could lead to accidents if the hood is open or if the hydraulic fluid leaks out of the vehicle.
GM has recalled 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year because of this issue.
The recall affects a total of 17,815 vehicles in this category.
The NHTSA has issued a warning to consumers about the potential safety risks associated with these vehicles.
Consumers should be aware that if their vehicle is involved in an accident, it may not be able to brake properly due to the faulty braking system.
This could lead to serious accidents and injuries.
The recall affects a total of 17,815 vehicles in this category.

The recall also affects 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year because of pressure accumulator issues that could cause hydraulic fluid to leak out during extreme cold temperatures.
This could make it harder for drivers to brake or steer, which could lead to accidents.
The recall affects a total of 17,815 vehicles in this category.
The NHTSA has issued a warning to consumers about the potential safety risks associated with these vehicles.
Consumers should be aware that if their vehicle is involved in an accident, it may not be able to brake properly due to the faulty braking system.
This could lead to serious accidents and injuries.
The recall affects a total of 17,815 vehicles in this category.

The recall also affects 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year because of pressure accumulator issues that could cause hydraulic fluid to leak out during extreme cold temperatures.
This could make it harder for drivers to brake or steer, which could lead to accidents.
The recall affects a total of 17,815 vehicles in this category.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles in the U.S., primarily from the 2004-2005 model years.
**Pickups, Vans, and SUVs**: Recalled 155,465 vehicles due to brake system issues that could cause pressure accumulator cracks.
Models affected are Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverade, Suburban, GMC Savana, Sierra, and Yukon.
**Cyclones**: Recalled 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs, and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans due to potential problems with the accelerator pedal in cold temperatures requiring more braking.
**Other Models**: GM recalled 17,815 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys, and Isuzu Ascenders from the 2005 model years because the windshield wasn't properly fitted during crashes.
GM noted that while there are details about some recalls, not all injuries are known.
The company also mentions a loss in European business, weak U.S. sales, and impacts on 2005 performance due to higher healthcare costs in North America and lower profits at financial services.
tinyllama:1.1b: Following the recall of nearly 200,000 vehicles by General Motors (GM) for braking system faults, the world's biggest carmaker has recalled over 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year.

The recall also includes 17,815 Buick Ranier, Chevy Trailblazer, GMC Envoy, Isuzu Ascender, and Cadillac XLR vehicles from the same year, but with additional braking system faults discovered in a product recall by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).
However, GM stressed that it did not know of any injuries related to these problems.
The recall comes as GM grapples with losses and poor US sales in 2005.

In January, the car giant also announced higher healthcare costs in North America, and lower profitability at its financial services subsidiary, Citigroup, which is slated for further restructuring this year.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The US has issued a safety recall for nearly 200,000 vehicles by General Motors (GM).
This is because the braking systems of these vehicles may be affected due to potential faults in the pressure accumulator inside the braking system.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) revealed that 155,465 pickup, van, and SUV vehicles have been recalled for this issue, with most affected from the 2004 and 2005 model years.
The recall was prompted by a problem where fragments of pressurized braking fluid could potentially harm people if they were left unattended while driving.
This is due to the potential for the fluid to leak and cause accidents or injuries.
The recalled vehicles include Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverado, and Suburban models from 2004 and 2005; as well as GMC Savana, Sierra, Yukon, from the same years.
The recall was announced by GM in a statement, and was prompted by concerns raised about potential safety issues by regulators within the NHTSA.
The car company is recalling these vehicles in an effort to protect its consumers, who could be at risk of accidents or injuries due to this issue.
The recalls come on the heels of a disappointing period for GM, which has seen its sales in Europe drop sharply and faced significant losses in its financial services unit.
The company is undergoing cost-cutting measures following these financial setbacks, which could affect its performance in the upcoming year.

The largest recall involves 155,465 pickups, vans, and SUVs from the 2004-2005 model years, and includes the Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverade, Suburban, GMC Savana, Sierra, Yukon, Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs, Pontiac Grand Prix sedans.

In addition to the braking system, the car giant is recalling 17,855 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys, and Isuzu Ascenders from the 2005 model years due to issues with their windshields.
GM stresses that no injuries have been reported related to these problems, but this recall comes as the company faces financial challenges and lower profits in North America and Europe.

This could make it harder to brake or steer and cause a crash.

In addition, the car giant is calling back 17,815 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys and Isuzu Ascenders from the 2005 model year because the windshield is not properly fitted and could fall out in a crash.
However, GM stressed that it did not know of any injuries related to the problems.
The recall follows an announcement last month that GM expects earnings this year be lower than in 2004.
The world's biggest car maker is grappling with losses in its European business, weak US sales and now a product recall.
hermes3:3b: GM recalls over 200k vehicles in US due to braking system issues (2004-2005 models), potential injuries from broken hoods & windshield falling out.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: General Motors (GM) has recalled nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US due to safety concerns, involving 155,465 pickups, vans, and SUVs with potential malfunctions in their braking systems from 2004 and 2005 model years.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) warns that a pressure accumulator in the braking system could crack during normal driving and fragment could injure people if the hood was open, causing leakage and making it harder to brake or steer, potentially leading to a crash.

In addition to the car recalls, GM is dealing with losses in its European business, weak US sales, and facing higher healthcare costs in North America and lower profits at its financial services subsidiary for the upcoming year.
stablelm2:1.6b: General Motors recalls nearly 4 million vehicles in the US due to safety concerns related to braking systems.
The largest recall involves pickups, vans, and SUVs from model years 2003-2010 as possible malfunctions with their braking systems could injure people if hood is open during an accident.
Additionally, Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs, and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans are also included in the recall for accelerator issues caused by extremely cold temperatures.
The company has not reported any injuries due to these problems.
This announcement follows news that GM expects earnings this year to be lower than previous years.
granite3.1-dense:2b: General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 US vehicles due to potential braking system malfunctions.
The largest recall involves 155,465 pickups, vans, and SUVs from the 2004 and 2005 model years, including Chevrolet Avalanche, Express, Kodiak, Silverade, Suburban; GMC Savana, Sierra, Yukon.
A pressure accumulator in these vehicles could crack during driving, causing hydraulic fluid leakage that might impair braking and steering, potentially leading to crashes if the hood is open.
Additionally, GM is recalling 19,924 Cadillac XLR coupes, SRX SUVs, and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans from the 2004 model year due to accelerator pedal issues in cold temperatures.

The company is also recalling 17,815 Buick Raniers, Chevrolet Trailblazers, GMC Envoys, and Isuzu Ascenders from the 2005 model years because their windshields may detach in crashes due to improper fitting.
Despite these issues, GM reported no known injuries related to the problems.

This recall comes amidst GM's announcement of lower expected earnings for 2005, following losses from its European business and weak US sales, as well as higher healthcare costs in North America and reduced profits at its financial services subsidiary.
chatgpt-4o-latest: General Motors (GM) is recalling nearly 200,000 vehicles in the US due to safety concerns.

The largest recall affects 155,465 pickups, vans, and SUVs from the 2004 and 2005 model years due to potential braking system malfunctions, which could lead to hydraulic fluid leaks and increased crash risks.

Additionally, 19,924 Cadillac, Pontiac, and other models from 2004 are being recalled due to accelerator pedal issues in extreme cold, and 17,815 vehicles from 2005 are being recalled for improperly fitted windshields.
GM stated it is unaware of any injuries related to these issues.
The recall comes amid financial struggles, including weak US sales, European losses, and rising healthcare costs.
